ARTHI 1.title: Introduction to Art
ARTHI 1.comments: Not open to Art History majors.
ARTHI 1.description: Course designed to develop basic visual skills and introduce students to the wide range of issues, works, and themes with which Art History is engaged.

ARTHI 5A.title: Introduction to Architecture and Environment
ARTHI 5A.description: Architecture is an act of place-making through which humans have constructed their relation with nature. Introduces the history of these strategies of place-making, interpretative concepts, and discipline-specific terminology in order to develop a critical understanding of the relationship between nature and built form.

ARTHI 5AH.title: Introduction to Architecture and Environment Honors Section
ARTHI 5AH.prereq_description: Consent of instructor; Concurrent enrollment in ARTHI 5A
ARTHI 5AH.description: Honors section to explore in greater depth topics and issues covered by ARTHI 5A. Requires concurrent enrollment in ARTHI 5A.

ARTHI 5B.title: Introduction to Museum Studies
ARTHI 5B.description: Designed to introduce students to various aspects of Museum Studies- historical, theoretical, and practical- by examining a range of issues and topics with which the field is engaged.

ARTHI 6A.title: Art Survey I: Ancient-Medieval Art
ARTHI 6A.description: History of western art from its origins to the beginnings of the renaissance.

ARTHI 6B.title: Art Survey II: Renaissance-Baroque Art
ARTHI 6B.description: Renaissance and baroque art in Northern and Southern Europe.

ARTHI 6C.title: Art Survey III: Modern-Contemporary Art
ARTHI 6C.description: History of western art from the 18th century to the present.

ARTHI 6DL.title: Survey: Landscape in China
ARTHI 6DL.description: A chronological survey of the evolution of landscape as subject matter in Chinese art and culture, from its origins in concepts of empire and domain, to the absorption of religious and philosophical values, to its later expression in the early modern and modern periods. The course ends with consideration of landscape's fate in contemporary society.

ARTHI 6DS.title: Survey: History of Art in China
ARTHI 6DS.description: Chronological and thematic overview of the major traditions of Chinese art, Neolithic to modern, including ceramics and bronzes, Buddhist visual culture, paintings, calligraphy, garden design and imperial architecture, with an emphasis on historical context, regional diversity, and intercultural encounters.

ARTHI 6DW.title: Survey: Art of Japan and Korea
ARTHI 6DW.description: Surveys the arts of Japan and the Korean peninsula from pre-historic to contemporary times. The focus is on the evolving role of the artist within society.

ARTHI 6E.title: Survey: Arts of Africa, Oceania, and Native North America
ARTHI 6E.description: A conceptual, cross-cultural introduction to Amerind, Eskimo, African, and Oceanic arts: artists, sculptures, festivals, body decoration, masking, architecture, and painting will be seen in the context of social and religious values. Films, slides, and museum tours.

ARTHI 6F.title: Survey: Architecture and Planning
ARTHI 6F.description: A selective and chronological survey of architecture and urban design in social and historical context. Individual buildings and urban plans from the past to the present will be used as examples.

ARTHI 6G.title: Survey: History of Photography
ARTHI 6G.description: A critical survey of nineteenth and twentieth century photography as an art form.

ARTHI 6H.title: Survey: Arts of the Ancient Americas
ARTHI 6H.description: An introduction to select art traditions from Mesoamerica to Andean South America. Examines architecture, ceramics, sculpture, painting and other classes of material culture for their meaning and function within sociopolitical, religious, and economic contexts.

ARTHI 6K.title: Survey: Islamic Art and Architecture
ARTHI 6K.description: A survey of Islamic art and architecture.

ARTHI 6KH.title: Survey: Islamic Art and Architecture Honors Section
ARTHI 6KH.prereq_description: Consent of instructor; Concurrent enrollment in Art History 6K
ARTHI 6KH.description: Honors section to explore in greater depth topics and issues covered by ARTHI 6K. Requires concurrent enrollment in ARTHI 6K.

ARTHI 6L.title: Playful Spaces: A Cultural History of Games
ARTHI 6L.description: This course introduces students to the history of games. It is organized chronologically as a global survey. We study games and the social, political, and economic conditions that support them, as well as the interface between the human player and the imagined world of the game. Taking as its premise that games are artifacts of culture, this course focuses on the visual and spatial practice of games in social context.

ARTHI 6M.title: Survey: Eccentric Images
ARTHI 6M.description: This course examines the history of art through some of its strangest images, including spatial illusions, chance images, hidden faces and monsters, reversible images, caricatures and others. Primarily focused on the early modern period (1400-1750), we also consider similar experiments from other cultures.

ARTHI 86.title: Research Seminar in History of Art & Architecture
ARTHI 86.description: Introduces students to current topics and debates in the history of art and architecture. Topics will vary. This course requires weekly readings and discussion, and the writing of a research seminar paper.

ARTHI 94S.title: Student Facilitated Group Studies Project
ARTHI 94S.prereq_description: A prior art history course; consent of instructor and department.
ARTHI 94S.comments: Students must have a cumulative 3.0 for the proceeding 2 quarter(s).
ARTHI 94S.description: Independent art history research conducted under the guidance of Art History faculty. Topic and scope varies, to be specified by student and supervisory faculty member prior to registration.

ARTHI 100.title: Methods for the History of Art and Architecture
ARTHI 100.prereq_description: Designed for majors. Not open to Freshmen.
ARTHI 100.description: Introduces History of Art & Architecture majors to the methods and skills of research and scholarship in the field.

ARTHI 103A.title: Roman Architecture
ARTHI 103A.description: The architecture and urban image of Rome and the Empire from the Republic through the Constantinian era.

ARTHI 103B.title: Roman Art: From the Republic to the Empire (509B.C. to A.D.   337)
ARTHI 103B.description: Painting, sculpture, and decorative arts of the Romans from the Republic to the Empire, from Romulus to Constantine. Social, economic, and cultural background emphasized.

ARTHI 103C.title: Greek Architecture
ARTHI 103C.description: The architecture of the Greek world from the archaic period through the Hellenistic age.

ARTHI 103D.title: Introduction to Classical Archaeology
ARTHI 103D.description: Introduces students to the field of Classical Archaeology through case studies drawn from all over the ancient world, with an emphasis on the Mediterranean. Explores both the practical methods of archaeology as well as the artifacts that are found and how they are preserved, displayed, and who owns them.

ARTHI 103E.title: Roman Art and Archaeology
ARTHI 103E.description: Provides an introduction to ancient Rome through the lens of material culture  -the art, architecture, and objects that surrounded people living in the city of Rome. Focuses primarily on the city of Rome - its buildings and its urban structure. Explores various topics and themes, including impacts of empire, social status, religion, gender, and the urban experience in antiquity.

ARTHI 103F.title: Greek Art and Archaeology
ARTHI 103F.description: Explores the ancient Greek world through art and archaeology-using art objects, architecture, and everyday artifacts to learn about ancient Greek society. Focuses on the history of Greek art, archaeology, and architecture from the Bronze Age through the Hellenistic period, and considers such themes as religion, politics, social status, and urban planning.

ARTHI 103G.title: Ancient Spectacle
ARTHI 103G.description: Explores the worlds of ancient Greece and Rome through the participants in and observers of a variety of spectacles in the ancient world. Examines public spectacles such as bull-  leaping, Olympic games, theatrical performances, gladiatorial combats, naval battles, religious rituals, and military triumphs, as well as other more private spectacles such as dinner parties with the gods.

ARTHI 103H.title: Archaeological Field School
ARTHI 103H.description: This course is an archaeological field school at the site of Settecamini, Italy. Students will learn excavation techniques, scientific testing, and digital methods of recording.

ARTHI 105C.title: Medieval Architecture: From Constantine to Charlemagne
ARTHI 105C.description: A survey of the architecture in Italy, France, Spain, Germany, and England from the early Christian through the Carolingian periods.

ARTHI 105E.title: The Origins of Romanesque Architecture
ARTHI 105E.description: Eleventh century architecture in France, Italy, Spain, Germany, and England.

ARTHI 105G.title: Late Romanesque and Gothic Architecture
ARTHI 105G.description: Twelfth and Thirteenth century architecture in France, Italy, Spain, Germany, and England.

ARTHI 105L.title: Art and Society in Late-Medieval Tuscany
ARTHI 105L.description: The dramatic developments in Central-Italian art from the eleventh to the fourteenth centuries are presented against a historical background: emergent capitalism, the gradual replacement of feudal authority with representative governments, popular religious movements and the first stirrings of humanism.

ARTHI 105M.title: The Design, Construction, and Structure of Medieval   Architecture
ARTHI 105M.description: The practical aspects of creating High Medieval Churches.

ARTHI 105O.title: The Global Middle Ages: Visual and Cultural Encounters in   the Medieval Mediterranean
ARTHI 105O.description: Focusing on the Mediterranean, this course considers visual manifestations of exchange. Its goal is to examine the complexity of religious, political, and visual interactions in the Middle Ages, a period that brought together diverse religious communities, generating both social frictions and new cultural forms. Students will study the dynamic interplay among Christian, Jewish, and Islamic visual cultures as they developed and coalesced through commerce, gift exchange, the reinterpretation of pre-existing forms, and the reuse of objects and spaces.

ARTHI 105P.title: Introduction to Medieval Art and Architecture
ARTHI 105P.description: This course explores the soaring cathedrals, monstrous sculptures, and marvelous images that inspired The Lord of the Rings and Game of Thrones. Beginning with the fourth-century rise of Christian images and ending with the advent of print, it traces how images developed new roles - and reinvented old ones - over the course of the Middle Ages. Investigating architecture, sculpture, and manuscripts in their historical contexts, it asks why medieval objects look the way the do and how viewers saw them.

ARTHI 105Q.title: Art and War
ARTHI 105Q.description: We often think about art as a bridge between cultures and look to masterpieces like the Sistine Chapel as the height of a nation's cultural achievements. But during times of war, art can become military targets and destroyed, or used to create enemies. Conversely, art has been employed to resist political establishments, critique violence, and provide therapy for veterans. Drawing examples from different time periods, this course investigates the myriad ways art has been used-and abused-during military conflict.

ARTHI 105R.title: Art of Medieval Spain: Visual and Cultural Encounters
ARTHI 105R.description: Focusing on medieval Spain, this course considers visual manifestations of exchange. Its goal is to examine the complexity of religious, political, and visual interactions on the Iberian Peninsula, where Christians, Muslims, and Jews "co-existed." Students will study the dynamic interplay among Christian, Jewish, and Islamic visual cultures as they developed and coalesced through conquest, commerce, gift exchange, social intermingling, and diplomatic relations.

ARTHI 107A.title: Painting in the 15th-Century Netherlands
ARTHI 107A.description: Netherlandish painting from C1400- C1500 examined in its social, religious,and cultural contexts. Van Eyck, Rogier, Bouts and Memling, among others.

ARTHI 107B.title: Painting in the 16th-Century Netherlands
ARTHI 107B.description: Painting of the low countries from C1500-C1600, placed in its social and cultural contexts. Artists studied include Bosch and Bruegel. continuation from 107A, but may be taken separately.

ARTHI 107C.title: Renaissance Kunst- and Wunderkammern: the First Museums
ARTHI 107C.description: In the sixteenth century, wealthy merchants and powerful princes in Europe began assembling vast collections that aspired to contain all possible knowledge of all possible things. From these remarkably diverse collections- called Kunst- and Wunderkammern (German), studioli (Italian), and curiosity cabinets (English)-arose our modern museums of art, science, history and technology, as well as modern research collections in universities.  This course explores these fascinating collections, the purposes that they served and the circumstances in which they were created.

ARTHI 107D.title: Puzzles and Vexations: Games in Early-Modern Art and Culture
ARTHI 107D.description: Explores the fascinating profusion of games in early-modern Europe, ca. 1400-1700, including card games, board games, and visual, mechanical and mathematical puzzles. Topics include the role of fate and chance; the phenomenon of puzzle pictures; illusionism and other eccentric images; and the social and moral implications of games.

ARTHI 108AAZZ.title: Special Topics in Fifteenth and Sixteenth Century Northern   European Art
ARTHI 108AAZZ.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 12 units provided letter designations are different.
ARTHI 108AAZZ.description: Specialized classes exploring critical issues in European art from the Netherlands, Germany, France, and/or England. Courses may take the form of in-depth studies of particular artists (e.g. Durer) or themes (e.g. iconoclasm).

ARTHI 109A.description: Developments in painting and sculpture, with attention to issues of technique, iconography, patronage, workshop culture and theory.

ARTHI 109B.description: Developments in a variety of artistic media with attention to issues of geography, empires, religion, workshop culture, and theory.

ARTHI 109C.title: Art, Science, and Technology in the Renaissance
ARTHI 109C.description: An approach to the art of the Renaissance that focuses on intersections with scientific and technological practices that conditioned its historical development.

ARTHI 109D.title: Art and the Formation of Social Subjects in the Early Modern Period
ARTHI 109D.description: An approach to the art of the Renaissance that focuses on the viewer's experience and the social and cultural conditions framing it.

ARTHI 109E.title: Michelangelo
ARTHI 109E.description: The career and achievement of the artist, with particular attention to issues surrounding his treatment of the human body.

ARTHI 109F.title: Italian Journeys
ARTHI 109F.description: A historical survey of travel to Italy and its importance as one of the constitutive rituals of western culture, drawing upon literature, the visual arts, and film, and ending with practical advice for those planning to make the trip themselves.

ARTHI 109G.title: Leonardo Da Vinci: Art, Science, and Technology in Early Modern Italy
ARTHI 109G.description: The life and work of Leonardo Da Vinci and a consideration of their place in the history of art as well as in the development of early modern science and technology.

ARTHI 111B.title: Dutch Art in the Age of Rembrandt
ARTHI 111B.prereq_description: At least one Art History course. Not open to freshman.
ARTHI 111B.description: Visual culture produced in Northern Netherlands between 1579 and 1648. Classes devoted to individual artists (e.g. Rembrandt, Frans Hals) and genres (e.g. landscapes, portraiture, history painting) in relation to material culture and thought of the period.

ARTHI 111C.title: Dutch Art in the Age of Vermeer
ARTHI 111C.prereq_description: At least one Art History course; not open to freshman.
ARTHI 111C.description: Visual culture produced in Northern Netherlands between 1648 and 1672. Classes devoted to individual artists (e.g. Rembrandt, Johannes Vermeer) and genres (e.g. landscapes, portraiture, history painting) in relation to material culture and thought of the period.

ARTHI 111F.title: Rethinking Rembrandt
ARTHI 111F.prereq_description: At least one Art History course. Not open to freshmen.
ARTHI 111F.description: In light of recent reevaluations of Rembrandt's biography and his oeuvre, this course examines questions of authenticity and authorship in light of artistic technique, subject matter, style, and patronage.

ARTHI 112.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 12 units provided letter designations are different.
ARTHI 112.description: Specialized classes that examine critical issues in Northern European visual culture of the seventeenth century. Courses may consider individual artists (e.g. Frans Hals, Vermeer) and/or subject genres (e.g. still-life, history painting, portraiture) in relation to the cultural function of Northern European imagery from the time of production until today.

ARTHI 113A.title: Seventeenth Century Art in Southern Europe
ARTHI 113A.comments: Not open to students who have completed Art History 113B.
ARTHI 113A.description: Painting and sculpture from Italy and Spain as well as France and Flanders examined in its cultural, political, and religious contexts with particular attention to relationships between regional traditions and international trends. Artists studied include Caravaggio, Bernini, Velazquez, Poussin, and Rubens.

ARTHI 113B.title: Seventeenth Century Art in Italy I
ARTHI 113B.comments: Not open to students who have completed Art History 113A.
ARTHI 113B.description: Italian painting, sculpture, architecture, and urbanism from the late sixteenth to late seventeenth centuries examined in its cultural, political, and religious contexts, with emphasis on the relationship between the arts. Focus on the earlier seventeenth century, including the work of Caravaggio, Carracci, and the young Bernini.

ARTHI 113F.title: Bernini and the Age of the Baroque
ARTHI 113F.description: Examines the life and work of Gianlorenzo Bernini, best known as a brilliant and innovative sculptor, in their historical context. Also considered is the international influence that Bernini exerted on seventeenth- and eighteeth-century art.

ARTHI 115A.comments: Not open for credit to students who have completed Art History 158A.
ARTHI 115A.description: Painting, sculpture, and architecture in Europe. Topics will change, but may include art and court culture, the Rococo, the rise of popular art and media.

ARTHI 115B.description: Painting, sculpture, and architecture in Europe from 1760 to 1810. Topics will change but may include art and the French Revolution and neoclassicism.

ARTHI 115D.title: Eighteenth-Century Art in Italy: The Age of the Grand Tour
ARTHI 115D.description: In the eighteenth-century Grand Tourists flocked to Italy to see the great works of the past, while contemporary art flourished. This course examines the works of artists such as Piranesi and Tiepolo, important building programs, and early public museums.

ARTHI 115E.title: The Grand Tour: Experiencing Italy in the Eighteenth Century
ARTHI 115E.description: In the eighteenth century Italy was a mecca for European travelers who sought to enjoy its culture, diversions, landscape, and society.  This course will examine the multifaceted experiences of these travelers and the ways in which they constitute the beginnings of the phenomenon of modern tourism.

ARTHI 116AAZZ.title: Special Topics in Eighteenth Century Art
ARTHI 116AAZZ.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 12 units provided letter designations are different.
ARTHI 116AAZZ.description: Special topics in eighteenth century art.

ARTHI 117B.description: Painting, sculpture, and architecture in Europe. Topics will change, but may include art in the Industrial Revolution, Impressionism, and Post-Impressionism.

ARTHI 117F.title: Impressionism and Post-Impressionism
ARTHI 117F.description: Impressionist and Post-Impressionist movement in France from 1863 through the first decade of the twentieth century and the advent of Cubism. Includes the work of Monet, Manet, Degas, Renoir, Pissarro, Van Gogh, Cezanne, Gauguin, and Seurat.

ARTHI 118AAZZ.title: Special Topics in Nineteenth Century Art
ARTHI 118AAZZ.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 12 units provided letter designations are different.
ARTHI 118AAZZ.description: Special topics in nineteenth century art.

ARTHI 119B.title: Contemporary Art
ARTHI 119B.description: Study of recent artistic developments, from pop to contemporary movements in painting, sculpture, and photography. Movements studied include minimal art, post-minimalism, process art, conceptual art, earthworks, pluralism, neoexpressionism, and issues of postmodern art and criticism.

ARTHI 119C.title: Expressionism to New Objectivity: Early Twentieth Century German Art
ARTHI 119C.description: Survey of modernist art movements in Germany, beginning with the expressionist phase around 1905 and concluding with the Bauhaus and New Objectivity phase up to 1933. Special emphasis on the historical and cultural context of German art, and its interaction with the international art scene.

ARTHI 119D.title: Art in the Post-Modern World
ARTHI 119D.description: An examination of the concepts of "Post-Modernism" in Euro-American visual arts, including painting, sculpture, architecture, graphic arts, and new experimental genres from the 1970's to the present.

ARTHI 119E.description: Introduction to the major movements of European modern art in the first half of the twentieth century. This course critically addresses the formation of avant-garde groups and movements in relation to political and social issues.

ARTHI 119F.description: An examination of major artistic developments in Europe and the United States after the Second World War. Includes such movements as Abstract Expressionism, Neo-Dada, and Pop Art. Explores such artistic practices as performance art, feminist art, and conceptual art.

ARTHI 119G.title: Critical Approaches to Visual Culture
ARTHI 119G.prereq_description: A prior course in art history; not open to freshmen.
ARTHI 119G.description: Critical ways of approaching and understanding a wide range of visual materials and images (paintings, ads, videos, etc.). Analytic approaches to culture and representation are used as a means of developing descriptive and interpretive skills.

ARTHI 120AAZZ.title: Special Topics in Twentieth-Century Modern Art
ARTHI 120AAZZ.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 12 units provided letter designations are different.
ARTHI 120AAZZ.description: Special topics in twentieth-century modern art.

ARTHI 121A.description: Painting, sculpture, architecture and decorative arts in the original 13 colonies, through the formation of the United States, to the crisis of the Civil War. Particular attention paid to environmental and social issues.

ARTHI 121B.description: Painting and human-made environments from the onset of the Civil War to just before World War II, tracing the role of art in the rise of modern, corporate America.

ARTHI 121C.title: Twentieth-Century American Art: Modernism and Pluralism, 1900-Present
ARTHI 121C.description: American painting in the twentieth-century, from the advent of modernism to yesterday.

ARTHI 121D.title: African American Art and the African Legacy
ARTHI 121D.description: Examination of the three centuries of African-American art in North America, the Carribean, and Brazil, stressing the African legacy. Colonial metalwork and pottery, folk or outsider genres, and mainstream nineteenth-and twentieth-century work are among traditions studied.

ARTHI 121E.title: Three-Dimensional Arts of the United States: Meaning, Context, Reception
ARTHI 121E.description: From Puritan gravestones to park fountains to war memorials, American sculpture has been a barometer of the political, cultural, religious and artistic trends of our society. Covers the carvings of the first settlements, figural sculpture of colonial America, and the various art movements and sculptural forms of the nineteenth and twentieth centuries as well as current controversies surrounding public art.

ARTHI 123D.title: Art of Colonial Mexico
ARTHI 123D.description: This advanced survey explores the art of colonial Mexico, or New Spain, from the 16th through 18th centuries and focuses on art and architecture's role in forming a colonial society. We discuss Indigenous experiences of colonialism and forms of resistance as well as how manuscripts, architecture, paintings, maps, featherworks, and public festivals constructed ideas of place, colonial society, and social identity.

ARTHI 127A.title: African Art I
ARTHI 127A.description: The relationship of art to life in sub-Saharan Africa. A cross-cultural survey of types, styles, history, and values of arts ranging from personal decoration to the state festival, stressing Ashanti, Ife, Benin, Yoruba, Cameroon.

ARTHI 127B.title: African Art II
ARTHI 127B.description: An in-depth continuation of Art History 127A in a seminar/discussion format. Selected topics in masking, figural sculpture, etc., and emphasis on African contexts of ritual and social life.

ARTHI 128.title: Special Topics in African Art
ARTHI 128.description: Topics cover art and new media and the changing roles of technology, patrons, collectors, museums and other emergent institutions of patronage in contemporary art.

ARTHI 130A.title: Pre-Columbian Art of Mexico
ARTHI 130A.description: The art and architecture of selected cultures of Northern Mesoamerica (non-Maya) from circa 1200 B.C. to the Conquest with an emphasis on iconographical and historical problems.

ARTHI 130B.title: Pre-Columbian Art of the Maya
ARTHI 130B.description: Exploration of the art of Maya-speaking cultures in Southern Mesoamerica using archaeological, epigraphic and ethnographic data to help reconstruct Maya religion and civilization.

ARTHI 130C.title: The Arts of Spain and New Spain
ARTHI 130C.description: Beginning with the Islamic Medieval and Renaissance arts of Spain, this course will chart their influence and transformation in the sixteenth and seventeenth century arts of the new world. Special emphasis on the creativeinteraction of the European and indigenous traditions in colonial arts of the Americans.

ARTHI 130D.title: Art and Archaeology of the Ancient Andes
ARTHI 130D.description: The architecture, ceramics, textiles, and other classes of material culture of Andean societies from 3000 B.C. to the Conquest examined within their cultural contexts with a focus on sociopolitical organization and cultural traditions.

ARTHI 130F.title: Art and Archaeology of Mesoamerica
ARTHI 130F.description: An introduction to the societies of Ancient Mesoamerica. The course examines sociopolitical, religious, and economic systems from the Olmec through Aztecs via the study of material culture - including art, architecture, and artifacts. Explores topics of identity, social status, and exchange.

ARTHI 130G.title: Art and Architecture of the North Coast of Peru
ARTHI 130G.description: The rise and fall of ancient societies of the north coast of Peru such as the Moche, Sican, and Chimu as well as their cultural antecedents as understood through the material record including architecture, ceramics, textiles, etc.

ARTHI 131AAZZ.title: Special Topics in Latin American Art
ARTHI 131AAZZ.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 12 units provided letter designations are different.
ARTHI 131AAZZ.description: Special topics in Latin American art.

ARTHI 132A.title: Mediterranean Cities
ARTHI 132A.description: An exploration of the most important Medieval cities of the Mediterranean world, their urban forms, layout, architecture, and physical patterns. Venice, Cairo, and Baghdad will be among the cities discussed.

ARTHI 132D.description: Islamic architecture between 650 and 1400 in its historical context.

ARTHI 132E.title: Islamic Architecture 1400-Modern
ARTHI 132E.comments: Not open for credit to students who have completed Art History 176B.
ARTHI 132E.description: Islamic architecture, 1400-modern, in its historical context.

ARTHI 132G.title: Monuments of Power
ARTHI 132G.description: Historical documents and contemporary interpretations are used to explore the ways in which messages of dominance and power were embedded into Islamic monuments from the seventh century to modern times. A comparative, cross-cultural approach focusing on the power of architectural monuments in relation to the power to create architectural monuments.

ARTHI 132I.title: Art of Empire
ARTHI 132I.description: Studies the visual culture of different empires, alone or in a comparative fashion. For example, Ottoman and Hapsburg; Ottomoman, Safavid, and Mughal; Mughal and British India; or the earlier empire of the Fatimids, Abbasids, and Umayyads of Syria and Spain.

ARTHI 132J.title: Modern Art of the Arab World
ARTHI 132J.description: Explores modern and contemporary art, artists and art movements of the Arab world from nineteenth century to the present.

ARTHI 132K.title: The Mosque in History
ARTHI 132K.description: Major historical and contemporary issues related to mosques as architecture and as social institutions. Working vocabulary of forms and visual knowledge of major monuments. Global context.

ARTHI 133AAZZ.title: Special Topics in Islamic Art
ARTHI 133AAZZ.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 12 units provided letter designations are different.

ARTHI 134A.title: Buddhist Art
ARTHI 134A.description: A survey of select forms of Indian, Chinese, and Japanese Buddhist art. Emphasis on Buddhist sculpture and Zen painting. Exploration of the correlation of religious values and art, transformation and adaptation of artistic traditions from one culture to another.

ARTHI 134B.title: Early Chinese Art
ARTHI 134B.description: A survey of the art and archaeology of Ancient China, from neolithic times through the Tang Dynasty (A.D. 618-906). Emphasis on the development and transformation of pictorial traditions, leading to early painting theory and practice.

ARTHI 134C.title: Chinese Painting I
ARTHI 134C.description: Chinese painting and theory, from beginnings through the fourteenth century.  Introduction to major developments and masters in their cultural context with a focus on meaning and agency.

ARTHI 134D.title: Art and Modern China
ARTHI 134D.comments: ARTHI 134D is the same course as CHIN 134D.
ARTHI 134D.description: An exploration of trends and issues in nineteenth and twentieth-century Chinese art, as China awakens and responds to the challenges of modernity and the West. Topics include the continuity of tradition, the exile identity, and trends after Tienanmen (1989).

ARTHI 134E.title: The Art of the Chinese Landscape
ARTHI 134E.description: Chinese approaches to landscape as subject matter in art, with a focus on painting and garden architecture. The course begins with the immortality cult in the Han Dynasty (206 B.C.-A.D.221) and ends with contemporary artists of the twentieth century.

ARTHI 134F.title: Arts of Japan
ARTHI 134F.description: Native traditions and foreign influences in the development of Japanese architecture, sculpture, painting, and minor arts.

ARTHI 134G.title: Japanese Painting
ARTHI 134G.description: The changing and entwined traditions of Japanese painting: those rooted in native concepts and practices and those derived from the Asian continent or Euro-America.

ARTHI 134H.title: Ukiyo-e: Pictures of the Floating World
ARTHI 134H.description: Japanese paintings and woodblock prints of the sixteenth through twentieth centuries, with emphasis on issues of genre and format.

ARTHI 134I.description: Exploration of a wide array of Japanese modern and contemporary visual culture in Japan. Emphasis on cultural cross-pollination and global interchange amidst shifting media environments. Topics may vary by year.

ARTHI 134J.title: Understanding Manga
ARTHI 134J.description: An introduction to the development of Manga (Japanese comics) in relation to other world-wide graphic narrative traditions, with special emphasis on  visual analysis and historical context.

ARTHI 134K.title: Chinese Calligraphy: History and Aesthetics
ARTHI 134K.description: Examines the different scripts in historical context, surveys significant movements and artists, and considers the ideas, theories and aesthetic principles that have enriched the art of writing to elite status in China.

ARTHI 135AA.title: Special Topics in Japanese Art
ARTHI 135AA.description: Special topics in Japanese Art. Varying topics.

ARTHI 135BB.title: Special Topics in Chinese Art
ARTHI 135BB.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 12 units provided topics are different.

ARTHI 136A.title: Nineteenth-Century Architecture
ARTHI 136A.description: The history of architecture and planning beginning with eighteenth-century architectural trends in Europe and concluding with late nineteenth-century efforts to reform the city. Exploration of the culture of nineteenth-century modernity through architecture and urban design centered around the themes of industrialization, colonialism, and the idea of landscape. The scope is global.

ARTHI 136B.title: Twentieth-Century Architecture
ARTHI 136B.description: The history of architecture from 1900 to the present. Examination of modern and post-modern architecture and city planning in its social, political, and artistic context. The scope is global.

ARTHI 136C.title: Architecture of the United States
ARTHI 136C.description: History of architecture and urban planning: buildings and builders, patrons and occupants, but especially the historical forces and events that transformed the landscape. Course subjects include art, design, technology, economics, politics, and social forces.

ARTHI 136D.title: Design & the American Architect
ARTHI 136D.description: Course examines problems faced by the architectural profession today, as well as the role played by architects in the design process and in society at large. It also reviews how the architectural profession has developed in the past two centuries.

ARTHI 136E.title: Food Space
ARTHI 136E.description: Introduces the modern history of spaces that have supported the production, supply, and consumption of food since the 19th-c within the global exchange of ideas, commodities, and dissemination of foodways under the aegis of colonialism and capitalism. We look at a range of spaces from the forest and farm to restaurants and residences. Our goal is to understand the role of architecture and planning in supporting the changing connections between different scales of food production and consumption.

ARTHI 136H.title: Housing American Cultures
ARTHI 136H.description: The history of American domestic architecture from the colonial period to the present within a framework of cultural plurality. Examination of the relation between ideas of domesticity, residential design, individual, regional, and ethnic choices.

ARTHI 136I.title: The City in History
ARTHI 136I.description: An historical introduction to the ideas and forms of cities with emphasis on modern urbanism. Examination of social theory to understand the role of industrial capitalism and colonialism in shaping the culture of modern cities, the relationship between the city and the country, the phenomena ofclass, race and ethnic separation.

ARTHI 136J.title: Landscape of Colonialism
ARTHI 136J.description: Examination of architecture, urbanism and the land scape of British and French colonialism between 1600 and 1950. Introduction to the different forms of colonialism, colonial ideology and the architecture of colonial encounter in North America, Asia, Africa and Australia.

ARTHI 136K.title: Modern Architecture in Early Twentieth-Century Europe

ARTHI 136L.title: From Modernism to Post-Modernism in European Architecture
ARTHI 136L.description: History of European architecture from the mid-twentieth century onwards with emphasis on alternatives to Modernism such as, for example, Post-Modernism, Deconstructivism, Critical Regionalism, Neo-Traditionalism, and Neo-Classicism.

ARTHI 136M.title: Revival Styles in Southern Californian Architecture
ARTHI 136M.description: Examines the history of styles in Californian architecture from the eighteenth century to the present. While the focus is on Southern California, such comparative phenomena as National Romanticism in Western Architecure and Critical Regionalism are incorporated.

ARTHI 136O.title: Sustainable Architecture: History and Aesthetics
ARTHI 136O.description: Course examines history and theory of sustainable and "green" architecture since the early twentieth century. Emphasis is placed on the critical analysis of a distinct "green" architectural aesthetic; the scope is global.

ARTHI 136OH.title: Sustainable Architecture: History and Aesthetics Honors   Section
ARTHI 136OH.prereq_description: Consent of instructor; Concurrent enrollment in ARTHI 136O.
ARTHI 136OH.description: Honors section to explore in greater depth topics and issues covered by ARTHI 136O. Requires concurrent enrollment in ARTHI 136O.

ARTHI 136P.title: Frank Lloyd Wright
ARTHI 136P.description: The career and work of Wright with emphasis on his ideas about architecture in relation to both nature and free, democratic society, his contemporaries, and his importance in the history of modern architecture in the US and beyond.

ARTHI 136Q.title: Deviant Domesticities
ARTHI 136Q.description: Suburban landscape, single-family detached house and the nuclear family, is both an architectural and a social pattern. Despite its ubiquity in North America, it now poses an acute challenge to ecological and economic sustainability.

ARTHI 136R.title: Architecture of the Americas
ARTHI 136R.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 12 units provided letter designations are different.
ARTHI 136R.description: From antiquity to the present North and South America have been home to a dizzying variety of architectural and urban traditions. Emphasis on the movement of ideas and people, as well as economic, social, technological and political influences.

ARTHI 136S.title: Contemporary Architecture
ARTHI 136S.description: Presents a critical overview of global architecture since 1990 and focuses on three conditions that have changed architectural practice: the impact of digital media and computer-aided design and construction, globalization and geo-  political shifts, and the environmental crisis.

ARTHI 136T.title: Building California: Architecture and the Creation of   California's Environment
ARTHI 136T.description: A focus on the history of designing and building California's modern, human-made environment. Surveys buildings of the earliest settlers, and the period from the Spanish colonization onward. Focusing on architecture and architectural history (and on cognate design disciplines such as landscape architecture and urban planning) the course discusses design and building activities that shaped California's built environment, among them, for example, projects for infrastructure, agriculture, industry, cities, civic buildings, housing, leisure, domestic architecture, interiors, and gardens.

ARTHI 136TH.title: Building California: Architecture and the Creation of   California's Environment Honors Section
ARTHI 136TH.prereq_description: Consent of instructor; Concurrent enrollment in ARTHI 136T.
ARTHI 136TH.comments: Concurrently offered with ARTHI 136T. Requires concurrent enrollment in ARTHI 136T.
ARTHI 136TH.description: Honors section to explore in greater depth topics and issues covered by ARTHI 136T. Requires concurrent enrollment in ARTHI 136T.

ARTHI 136U.title: Designing a Better Tomorrow: Modern Architecture and   Utopia, from the Nineteenth Century to Today
ARTHI 136U.description: Depictions of Utopia have often shared an interest in conceiving ideal communities inhabiting a perfect, man-made environment. Focusing on visionary architectural designs from the nineteenth century onward, such as Utopian-socialist community projects, garden cities, total-works-of-art, Bauhaus, extraterrestrial habitats, and eco cities, discusses the history of modern architecture as exemplifying mankind's utopian longings. Part of this history are also dystopian failures like uninhabitable social housing estates, unlivable modern cities, and unfulfilled promises of social and ecological justice.

ARTHI 136UH.title: Designing a Better Tomorrow: Modern Architecture and   Utopia, from the Nineteenth Century to Today Honors Section
ARTHI 136UH.description: Honors section to explore in greater depth topics and issues covered by ARTHI 136U. Requires concurrent enrollment in ARTHI 136U.

ARTHI 136V.title: Modern Indian Visual Culture
ARTHI 136V.description: Introduction of twentieth-century visual culture in India, including painting, architecture, film, television, and graphic arts. Focuses on the themes of nationalism, modernity, and globalization, and the role of the "popular" in Indian visual culture.

ARTHI 136W.title: Introduction to 2D/3D Visualizations in Architecture
ARTHI 136W.prereq_description: Upper-division standing; open to majors only.
ARTHI 136W.description: Develops skills in reading, interpreting, and visualizing 3D objects and spaces by offering exercises in sketching, perspective, orthographic projections, isometric drawings, and manual rendering practices. Relevant for those interested in history of architecture, sculpture, and such spatial practices as installations and public art.

ARTHI 136X.title: Culture of Architecture: Perception and Analysis of the Built Environment
ARTHI 136X.description: Introduces the student to a first-hand experience of the built-environment through perception and analysis of design; understanding historical, theoretical, technical and artistic structures that shape and sustain the culture of architecture.

ARTHI 136Y.title: Modern Architecture in Southern California, C. 1890s to the Present
ARTHI 136Y.description: Critically analyzes the changing definitions of modern architecture in Southern California from the 1890s to the present, focusing on the work of architects like Greene and Greene, R.M. Schindler, and R. Neutra, as well as the Case Study Houses.

ARTHI 137AAZZ.title: Special Topics in Architecture
ARTHI 137AAZZ.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 12 units provided letter designations are different.

ARTHI 138G.title: The Social Production of Art: Patrons, Dealers, Critics, Museums
ARTHI 138G.prereq_description: Two prior upper-division art history courses.
ARTHI 138G.description: In contrast to the usual focus on the artist's creative activity, this course explores the crucial contributions made to the production of art by agencies such as markets, museums, exhibitions, reproductions, criticism, patronship, advertisement, etc.

ARTHI 139AAZZ.title: Special Topics in Photographic History
ARTHI 139AAZZ.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 12 units provided letter designations are different.
ARTHI 139AAZZ.description: Specialized classes exploring questions of methodology, as well as significant themes and major figures in the history of photography. Emphasis on intensive investigation of research issues as opposed to extensive period coverage.

ARTHI 141A.title: Museum Practices and Techniques
ARTHI 141A.prereq_description: Not open to freshmen; consent of instructor.
ARTHI 141A.comments: Not open for credit to student who have completed Art History 164C.
ARTHI 141A.description: Discussion of various aspects of museum work: management principles, the cataloging and care of art objects, exhibitions and acquisitions, administrative procedures, museum architecture. Specialist lectures and visits of museums and their facilities.

ARTHI 141C.title: Visual Technologies Internship
ARTHI 141C.prereq_description: Upper-division standing; consent of instructor and department.
ARTHI 141C.comments: Students must have a 3.0 GPA. May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 12 units (in ARTHI 141B, 141C and 141E), but no units count toward the major.
ARTHI 141C.description: An internship in the Visual Resource Collection to develop skills in the visual technologies relevant to art history teaching and research. Three hours per week per unit (total 30 hours/unit), plus weekly meetings and final evaluation session. Written report required.

ARTHI 141D.title: Birth of the Modern Museum
ARTHI 141D.description: Course examines the emergence and development of museums of art in eighteenth-century Europe, tracing their origins to the private collections from which they evolved and studying the practices, such as tourism, that stimulated their growth.

ARTHI 141G.title: The Architecture of Museums and Galleries from c. 1800 to the   Present
ARTHI 141G.description: Discusses the history of museums and galleries as distinct modern building types by analyzing their architectural developments from approximately 1800 to the present.  Beside architectural design issues (sequence of galleries, display of exhibits, lighting, visitor routes, etc.), the course analyzes museums as sites of memory, their intersections with the modern city, and their roles in cultural and societal debates.  Geographically, the course focuses on both the museum's origin in Europe and its contemporary universal presence.

ARTHI 141GH.title: The Architecture of Museums and Galleries from c. 1800 to   the Present Honors Section
ARTHI 141GH.description: Honors section to explore in greater depth topics and issues covered by ARTHI 141G. Requires concurrent enrollment in ARTHI 141G.

ARTHI 141MH.title: Museums and History
ARTHI 141MH.description: Examines the 20th century museum's engagement with history. Explores curatorial strategies for telling stories about the past through historical objects, written narratives, photography, performance, architecture, and art.

ARTHI 142A.title: Architecture and Planning in Seventeenth-Century Europe
ARTHI 142A.description: How did major changes in politics, science, and religion (absolutism, Scientific Revolution, Counter Reformation) manifest themselves in contemporary architecture and town planning? Architects include Bernini, Borromini, Wren, Mansart. Focus on Rome, Turin, Paris, and London.

ARTHI 142B.title: Architecture and Planning in Rome: Napoleon to Mussolini
ARTHI 142B.description: Transformation of Rome from a pre-modern to a modern city. Napoleonic occupations of 1798-1814; papal initiatives from 1815-70; Rome transformed into the new national capital 1870-  1922; Mussolini's massive public works in the 1920s and 30s.

ARTHI 142C.title: Paris and Rome in the Nineteenth Century

ARTHI 142D.description: Changing nature of garden and landscape design from the Renaissance to NYC's Central Park, studied as a function of the changing functions and status of land during the long passage from feudalism to industrial capitalism.

ARTHI 142E.title: Architecture, Planning, and Culture in Eighteenth-Century   Paris
ARTHI 142E.description: Paris (and Versailles) from the Sun King to the Revolution, rococo, neoclassicism, origins of urbanism; extensive use of primary texts in translation to study architectural debates in the press and their connection to contemporary political battles.

ARTHI 142F.title: Architecture, Theory & Town Planning in 19th Century France
ARTHI 142F.description: The French Revolution inspired a total rethinking: one that aspired to construct a new world and make new sense of the past. This rethinking encompassed politics, religion, history, science, technology, economics, government, philosophy - all of which are aspects of architecture, architectural theory, and town planning. This course will approach the history of 19th-century French architectural thought and practice as a lens through which to discern the broader ways in which the world changed in the wake of 1789.

ARTHI 143E.title: Adaptive Reuse and Art
ARTHI 143E.description: Most public places, buildings, galleries, and museums are transformed to varying degrees over the course of their history. This lecture explores how contemporary architects and artists rethought and repurposed historic structures.

ARTHI 143F.title: Architectural Criticism and Exhibitions: Exploring the Holdings of the Architecture & Design Collections
ARTHI 143F.description: Designed to give an introduction to archival research and highlight the differences between the physical and the virtual. The museum holdings will accompany us on the quest of understanding the difference between the material qualities of the architect's work and their impact on culture at large.

ARTHI 144A.title: The Avantgarde in Russia
ARTHI 144A.comments: Same course as Slavic 130A. Not open for credit to students who have completed Russian 144A or Slavic 144A.
ARTHI 144A.description: The Russian avantgarde in its European context. The avantgarde and the revolution of 1917. Analysis of key figures and movements within the Russian avantgarde. Taught in English.

ARTHI 144C.title: Contemporary Art in Russia and Eastern Europe
ARTHI 144C.comments: Same course as Slavic 130C. Not open for credit to students who have completed Russian 144C or Slavic 144C.
ARTHI 144C.description: Study of central intellectual and aesthetic trends in the late Soviet period and in contemporary post-Soviet Russia and Eastern Europe. Analysis of literary texts and the visual arts. Taught in English.

ARTHI 144D.title: Russian Art
ARTHI 144D.comments: Same courseas Slavic 130D. Not open for credit to students who have completed Russian 118 or Slavic 118.
ARTHI 144D.description: Introduction to Russian art and aesthetic theory from the beginning to the present. Readings and lectures in English.

ARTHI 148A.description: Study of recent artistic developments from 1960 until 2000.  Movements studied include minimalism, conceptual art, earthworks, feminist art, AIDS activism, identity politics, the use of new media and technology (video, digital media) in contemporary art, along with issues related to sexuality and difference.

ARTHI 148B.description: Broad introduction to the visual art and ideas of contemporary art history and its practice. Interdisciplinary and intermedia practices will be emphasized.  Topics include identity politics, multiculturalism, biennial culture, fabrication and scale, audience, and issues of reception and display.

ARTHI 148C.title: Art in California
ARTHI 148C.description: As a state, California is the site of tremendous diversity in the visual arts but has consistently suffered from stereotypes that framed it as a regional backwater far from New York and Europe. This lecture-based course addresses the character and role of the post-war art and its developments in and beyond the cities of Los Angeles and San Francisco. Movements studied include Mexican Muralism, the rise of modern photography, Asian American culture, assemblage and sculpture, the Black Arts movement, feminism, as well as pioneering developments in installation, video and performance art.

ARTHI 163.title: Digital Visual Studies
ARTHI 163.comments: Same course as Comparative Literature 163 and German 163.
ARTHI 163.description: In the past ten years, the scope of the digital humanities has broadened to include the visual world: "distant reading" became "distant viewing". This visual turn has not only facilitated the digital transformation of traditional disciplines like art history but has also introduced a new set of media-technological questions into the digital humanities discourse: questions concerning the nature of digital images, and the modalities of machine seeing. This course serves as an introduction to the emerging discipline of "digital visual studies" that investigates these questions. Participants will acquire skills in the analysis and critique of digital visual culture and learn to use contemporary digital tools to explore the visual world.

ARTHI 185AAZZ.title: Special topics in Art History
ARTHI 185AAZZ.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 12 units provided letter designations are different.
ARTHI 185AAZZ.description: Special topics in the history of art and architecture.

ARTHI 186A.title: Seminar in Research Methods
ARTHI 186A.description: A focus on methodological approaches and tools. Topics will vary. Requires weekly readings and discussion, and the writing of a research seminar paper.

ARTHI 186B.title: Seminar in Ancient Greek & Roman Art/Architecture
ARTHI 186B.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 8 units.  Open only to Art History majors during Pass 1.
ARTHI 186B.description: Advanced studies in Ancient Greek and Roman archaeology and architecture. Emphasis on classical heritage of Asia Minor (Turkey). Topics will vary. This course requires weekly readings and discussion, and the writing of a research seminar paper.

ARTHI 186C.title: Seminar in Medieval Art
ARTHI 186C.comments: Open only to Art History majors during Pass 1.
ARTHI 186C.description: Advanced studies in Medieval art. Topics will vary. This course requires weekly readings and discussion, and the writing of a research seminar paper.

ARTHI 186D.title: Seminar in Medieval Architecture & Sculpture
ARTHI 186D.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 8 units.  Open only to Art History majors during Pass 1.
ARTHI 186D.description: Advanced studies in Medieval architecture and sculpture. Topics will vary. This course requires weekly readings and discussion, and the writing of a research seminar paper.

ARTHI 186E.title: Seminar in Fifteenth and Sixteenth Century Northern European Art
ARTHI 186E.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 8 units with different topic.  Open only to Art History majors during Pass 1.
ARTHI 186E.description: Advanced studies in fifteenth and sixteenth century Northern European art. Topics will vary. This course requires weekly readings and discussion, and the writing of a research seminar paper.

ARTHI 186F.title: Seminar in Fifteenth and Sixteenth Century Southern Renaissance
ARTHI 186F.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 8 units with different topic.  Open only to Art History majors during Pass 1.
ARTHI 186F.description: Advanced studies in fifteenth and sixteenth century Southern Renaissance art. Topics will vary. This course requires weekly readings and discussion,and the writing of a research seminar paper.

ARTHI 186G.title: Seminar in Seventeenth Century Northern European Art
ARTHI 186G.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 8 units with different topic.  Open only to Art History majors during Pass 1.
ARTHI 186G.description: Advanced studies in seventeenth century Northern European visual culture. Topics will vary. This course requires weekly readings and discussion, and the writing of a research seminar paper.

ARTHI 186H.title: Seminar in Seventeenth Century Southern European Art
ARTHI 186H.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 8 units.  Open only to Art History majors during Pass 1.
ARTHI 186H.description: Advanced studies in seventeenth century art. Topics will vary. Requires weekly readings and discussion, and the writing of a research seminar paper.

ARTHI 186J.title: Seminar in Nineteenth Century Modern Art
ARTHI 186J.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 8 units with different topic.  Open only to Art History majors during Pass 1.
ARTHI 186J.description: Advanced studies in nineteenth century modern art. Topics will vary. This course requires weekly readings and discussion, and the writing of a research seminar paper.

ARTHI 186JS.title: Seminar in Contemporary Art
ARTHI 186JS.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 8 units.  Open only to Art History majors during Pass 1.
ARTHI 186JS.description: Advanced studies in contemporary art. Topics will vary. This course requires weekly readings and discussion, and the writing of a research seminar paper.

ARTHI 186K.title: Seminar in Twentieth Century Modern Art & Visual Culture
ARTHI 186K.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 8 units.  Open only to Art History majors during Pass 1.
ARTHI 186K.description: Advanced studies in twentieth century modern art. Topics will vary. This course requires weekly readings and discussion, and the writing of a research seminar paper.

ARTHI 186L.title: Seminar in Art of the Americas
ARTHI 186L.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 8 units with different topic.  Open only to Art History majors during Pass 1.
ARTHI 186L.description: Advanced studies in the art of the Americas. Topics will vary. This course requires weekly readings and discussion, and the writing of a research seminar paper.

ARTHI 186N.title: Seminar in African Art
ARTHI 186N.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 8 units with different topic.  Open only to Art History majors during Pass 1.
ARTHI 186N.description: Advanced studies in African art. Topics will vary. This course requires weekly readings and discussion, and the writing of a research seminar paper.

ARTHI 186O.title: Seminar in Latin American Art
ARTHI 186O.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 8 units with different topic.  Open only to Art History majors during Pass 1.
ARTHI 186O.description: Advanced studies in Latin American Art. Topics will vary. This course requires weekly readings and discussion, and the writing of a research seminar paper.

ARTHI 186P.title: Seminar in Latin American Art
ARTHI 186P.comments: Open only to Art History majors during Pass 1.
ARTHI 186P.description: Advanced studies in pre-Columbian/colonial art. Topics will vary. This course requires weekly readings and discussion, and the writing of a research seminar paper.

ARTHI 186Q.title: Seminar in Islamic Art and Architecture
ARTHI 186Q.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 8 units with different topic.  Open only to Art History majors during Pass 1.
ARTHI 186Q.description: Advanced studies in Islamic art and architecture. Topics will vary. This course requires weekly readings and discussion, and the writing of a research seminar paper.

ARTHI 186R.title: Seminar in Asian Art
ARTHI 186R.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 8 units with different topic.  Open only to Art History majors during Pass 1.
ARTHI 186R.description: Advanced studies in Asian art. Topics will vary. This course requires weekly readings and discussion, and the writing of a research seminar paper.

ARTHI 186RS.title: Seminar in Chinese Art
ARTHI 186RS.comments: Open only to Art History majors during Pass 1.
ARTHI 186RS.description: Advanced studies in Chinese art. Topics vary. Requires weekly readings and discussion, and the writing of a research seminar paper.

ARTHI 186RW.title: Seminar in Japanese Art
ARTHI 186RW.description: Studies in Japanese art. Topics will vary, but emphasis is usually on the various relationships to global movements.  Requires weekly readings, discussion, frequent presentations, and the writing of a well-developed research paper.

ARTHI 186SJ.title: Seminar in American Architectural History
ARTHI 186SJ.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 8 units.  Open only to Art History majors during Pass 1.
ARTHI 186SJ.description: Advanced studies in American architectural history. Topics will vary. This course requires weekly readings and discussion, and the writing of a research seminar paper.

ARTHI 186SR.title: Seminar in Architectural History
ARTHI 186SR.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 8 units.  Open only to Art History majors during Pass 1.
ARTHI 186SR.description: Advanced studies in architectural history. Topics will vary. This course requires weekly readings and discussion, and the writing of a research seminar paper.

ARTHI 186SS.title: Seminar in Architectural History & Urbanism
ARTHI 186SS.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 8 units.  Open only to Art History majors during Pass 1.
ARTHI 186SS.description: Advanced studies in architectural history and urbanism. Topics will vary. This course requires weekly readings and discussion, and the writing of a research seminar paper.

ARTHI 186SV.title: Seminar in Modern Architecture
ARTHI 186SV.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 8 units.  Open only to Art History majors during Pass 1.
ARTHI 186SV.description: Advanced studies in modern architecture. Topics will vary. This course requires weekly readings and discussion, and the writing of a research seminar paper.

ARTHI 186T.title: Seminar in Photographic History
ARTHI 186T.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 8 units with different topic.  Open only to Art History majors during Pass 1.
ARTHI 186T.description: Advanced studies in photographic history. Topics will vary. This course requires weekly readings and discussion, and the writing of a research seminar paper.

ARTHI 186V.title: Seminar: Theory, Method & Historiography
ARTHI 186V.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 8 units.  Open only to Art History majors during Pass 1.
ARTHI 186V.description: Advanced studies in art theory. Topics will vary. This course requires weekly readings and discussion, and the writing of a research seminar paper.

ARTHI 186Y.title: Seminar in Architecture and Environment
ARTHI 186Y.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 8 units. Open only to Art History majors during Pass 1.
ARTHI 186Y.description: Advanced studies in architecture and environment. Topics vary including active archival research. The course requires weekly readings and discussions, and the writing of a research seminar paper.

ARTHI 187A.title: Approaches to Objects
ARTHI 187A.description: This seminar introduces students to the potential and different approaches of object-based scholarship drawing on multidisciplinary perspectives and analytic techniques from art history, archaeology, anthropology, object conservation, and the history of collecting and display. Topics and format will vary.

ARTHI 187B.title: Public Art
ARTHI 187B.description: This seminar explores the history and development of public art and monuments.  Together we study examples of various types of public art and consider their purposes, sites, audiences, patronage, and financing.  We also discuss important controversies that public art has provoked.  Using the background we develop in class, students work on individual projects addressing issues that we examine.

ARTHI 187C.title: Museum Theory: Collections and Cultural Politics
ARTHI 187C.prereq_description: Upper-division standing; art history majors only.
ARTHI 187C.comments: Designed for majors. Open only to Art History majors during Pass 1.
ARTHI 187C.description: Why do museums (whether of art, culture, history, science, religion, technology or otherwise) seem to generate unending controversies concerning ethics, cultural politics, authenticity and ownership? Through the lens of wide-ranging readings in museum theory, this seminar examines the museum as an institution and a set of cultural practices, exploring recent museum controversies and debating the merits of the  exhibitions and the efficacy of the responses.

ARTHI 187H.title: Museums in Transition: From the Early Modern to the Modern   Period
ARTHI 187H.description: Examines a range of issues-art historical, cultural, political, practical, and theoretical-that conditioned the development of museums and collections, primarily in Europe, from the Renaissance to the present day. Topics and format will vary.

ARTHI 187W.title: Coming Home: The House Museum as Cultural Encounter
ARTHI 187W.comments: Designed for majors. Open only to Art History majors during Pass 1.
ARTHI 187W.description: This seminar studies the political and cultural history of the house museum in the United States, from its antebellum beginnings in the nineteenth century to the present. Explores a variety of issues related to the house museum, including curatorial and design choices, visitor experiences, and the House Museum Movement.

ARTHI 187Z.title: Museum Studies Seminar
ARTHI 187Z.prereq_description: Upper-division standing; art history majors only.
ARTHI 187Z.comments:
Open only to Art History majors during Pass 1.
Repeat Comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 12 units.
ARTHI 187Z.description: Examines a range of historical, theoretical, and practical issues with which the field of Museum Studies is engaged.  Topics and format will vary.

ARTHI 192AAZZ.title: Internship in the History of Art & Architecture
ARTHI 192AAZZ.comments:
Enrollment in the course is subject to the student securing an internship. Internships are not provided by the department.
Repeat Comments: Interns may earn credit for a maximum of 12 units, but only 4 units may count toward the major.
ARTHI 192AAZZ.description: Under supervision of History of Art & Architecture faculty, students may obtain credit for work in a museum, gallery, or architecture firm. Students earn one unit for every 30 hours of work in their internship. Regular meetings, a final evaluation session, and a written report are required.

ARTHI 192A.title: University Art Museum Internship
ARTHI 192A.comments:
Enrollment in the course is subject to the student securing an internship. Internships are not provided by the department.
Repeat Comments: Interns may earn credit for a maximum of 12 units, but only 4 units may count toward the major.
ARTHI 192A.description: Under supervision of History of Art & Architecture faculty, students may obtain credit for work in the University Art Museum. Students earn one unit for every 30 hours of work in their internship. Regular meetings, a final evaluation session, and a written report are required.

ARTHI 192B.title: Architecture and Design Collective Internship
ARTHI 192B.comments:
Enrollment in the course is subject to the student securing an internship. Internships are not provided by the department.
Repeat Comments: Interns may earn credit for a maximum of 12 units, but only 4 units may count toward the major.
ARTHI 192B.description: Under supervision of History of Art & Architecture faculty, students may obtain credit for work in the Architecture and Design Collection. Students earn one unit for every 30 hours of work in their internship. Regular meetings, a final evaluation session, and a written report are required.

ARTHI 192C.title: Visual Technologies Internship
ARTHI 192C.comments:
Enrollment in the course is subject to the student securing an internship. Internships are not provided by the department.
Repeat Comments: Interns may earn credit for a maximum of 12 units, but only 4 units may count toward the major.
ARTHI 192C.description: An internship in the Visual Resource Collection to develop skills in the visual technologies relevant to art history teaching and research. Three hours per week per unit (total 30 hours/unit), plus weekly meetings and final evaluation session. Written report required.

ARTHI 192D.title: On Campus Internship in the History of Art & Architecture
ARTHI 192D.comments:
Enrollment in the course is subject to the student securing an internship. Internships are not provided by the department.
Repeat Comments: Interns may earn credit for a maximum of 12 units, but only 4 units may count toward the major.
ARTHI 192D.description: Under supervision of History of Art & Architecture faculty, students may obtain credit for internship work on UCSB's campus, excluding the ADA Museum, the ADC, and the IRC internships. Students earn one unit for every 30 hours of work in their internship. Regular meetings, a final evaluation session, and a written report are required.

ARTHI 192E.title: Off Campus Internship in the History of Art & Architecture
ARTHI 192E.comments:
Enrollment in the course is subject to the student securing an internship. Internships are not provided by the department.
Repeat Comments: Interns may earn credit for a maximum of 12 units, but only 4 units may count toward the major.
ARTHI 192E.description: Under supervision of History of Art & Architecture faculty, students may obtain credit for work in a museum, gallery, or architecture firm. Students earn one unit for every 30 hours of work in their internship. Regular meetings, a final evaluation session, and a written report are required.

ARTHI 194S.title: Student Facilitated Group Studies Project
ARTHI 194S.prereq_description: Upper-division standing; consent of instructor and department.
ARTHI 194S.comments: Students must have a cumulative 3.0 for the proceeding 3 quarter(s).
ARTHI 194S.description: Independent Art History research conducted under the guidance of Art History faculty. Topic and scope varies, to be specified by student and supervisory faculty member prior to registration.

ARTHI 198.title: Independent Readings in Art History
ARTHI 198.comments: Students must have a 3.0 GPA and are limited to 5 units per quarter and 12 unit total. Students are limited to 30 units total in all 98/99/198/199/199AA-ZZ courses combined.
ARTHI 198.description: Intended for students who know their own reading needs. Normally requires regular meetings with the instructor.

ARTHI 199.title: Independent Studies
ARTHI 199.prereq_description: Upper-division standing; two upper-division courses in art history; consent
ARTHI 199.comments: Students must have a minimum 3.0 grade-point average for the preceding three quarters and are limited to 5 units per quarter and 30 units total inall 98/99/198/199/199AA-ZZ courses combined.
ARTHI 199.description: Advanced individual problems.  Each unit requires 30 hours per quarter of work from the student.

ARTHI 199RA.title: Undergraduate Research Assistant
ARTHI 199RA.prereq_description: Upper-division standing; two upper-division courses in art history; consent
ARTHI 199RA.comments: Students must have a 3.0 cumulative grade-point average and are limited to 5 units per quarter and 30 units total in all 98/99/198/199/199AA-ZZ courses combined.
ARTHI 199RA.description: Undergraduate research assistant.  Each unit requires 30 hours per quarter of work from the student.

ARTHI 200A.title: Proseminar: Introduction to Art-Historical Methods
ARTHI 200A.prereq_description: Graduate standing. Art History majors only.
ARTHI 200A.comments: Required of all first-year M.A./Ph.D. students.
ARTHI 200A.description: Introduction to art-historical methods, with emphasis on the historical development of current practices, critical theory, debates within the field, and cross-disciplinary dialogues.

ARTHI 251A.title: Seminar: Topics in African & African-American Art
ARTHI 251A.description: Special research in African & African-American art.

ARTHI 251B.title: Seminar: Topics in African Arts in Context

ARTHI 252B.title: Seminar: Topics in Roman Architecture and Urbanism
ARTHI 252B.prereq_description: Graduate standing or senior art history majors with consent of instructor.
ARTHI 252B.description: Special research in Roman and late antique architecture.

ARTHI 253D.title: Seminar: Topics in Medieval Architecture & Sculpture
ARTHI 253D.description: Special research in Romanesque and/or Gothic architecture and sculpture.

ARTHI 254.title: Seminar: Topics in Pre-Columbian/Colonial Latin American Art
ARTHI 254.description: Special research in pre-Columbian and colonial Latin American art topics.

ARTHI 255D.title: Seminar: Topics in 15th & 16th C. Art in Northern Europe
ARTHI 255D.description: Special research in northern Renaissance figurative arts of the fifteenth and/or sixteenth centuries.

ARTHI 255G.title: Seminar: Studies in the History and Theory of Museums
ARTHI 255G.description: Special research in museum history and theory.

ARTHI 256.title: Topics in Early Modern Iberian Art
ARTHI 256.description: This seminar explores a variety of topics in the arts and visual cultures of the Iberian world at large, from 1450 to 1700.

ARTHI 257A.title: Seminar: Topics in Seventeenth-Century European Art
ARTHI 257A.description: Special topics in seventeenth-century European Art.

ARTHI 259A.title: Seminar: Topics in Nineteenth-Century European Art

ARTHI 260D.title: Seminar: Topics in European Art of the Twentieth Century

ARTHI 261A.title: Seminar: Topics in American Art
ARTHI 261A.description: Special research in American painting and sculpture, 1700-1950.

ARTHI 261E.title: Seminar: Topics in History of Photography
ARTHI 261E.description: Special problems in the history of photography.

ARTHI 265.title: Seminar: Topics in Architectural History & Urbanism
ARTHI 265.description: Special research in the history of architecture.

ARTHI 266.title: Seminar: Topics in Early Modern Architecture
ARTHI 266.description: Special research in early modern architecture.

ARTHI 275B.title: Seminar: Topics in Islamic Art & Architecture
ARTHI 275B.description: Special research in Islamic art and architecture.

ARTHI 275E.title: Seminar: Topics in Islamic Art
ARTHI 275E.description: Special topics in Islamic art and/or architecture. Topics will vary.

ARTHI 282A.title: Seminar: Topics on East Asian Art
ARTHI 282A.description: Research on select problems on the arts of China, Japan, or Korea.

ARTHI 282B.title: Seminar: Topics of Japanese Art
ARTHI 282B.description: Studies in Japanese art in a comparative context. Topics vary, but emphasis is usually on the various relationships to global movements.  Requires weekly readings, discussion, frequent presentations, and the writing of a well-developed research paper.

ARTHI 293D.title: Seminar: Research Methods
ARTHI 293D.description: A focus on methodological approaches and tools employed in digital humanities.

ARTHI 294.title: Seminar: Museum Practices
ARTHI 294.description: Methods in museum practice. Content will vary according to museum program and art exhibition involved.

ARTHI 295.title: Seminar: Advanced Readings in Art History
ARTHI 295.prereq_description: Graduate standing; consent of instructor; department approval.
ARTHI 295.description: Source readings for graduate students. Independent reading and research in connection with an undergraduate lecture course.

ARTHI 296A.title: READING CRITICAL THEORY AND THE VISUAL ARTS
ARTHI 296A.description: Analysis of theories and critiques of modernism and modernity from Benjaminto Adorno and Derrida, with special focus on the historical avantgarde. Specifics may vary.

ARTHI 297.title: Seminar: Getty Consortium
ARTHI 297.description: Special graduate seminar offered at the Getty Research Institute in Los Angeles, involving faculty and graduate students from the five graduate programs in Art History of Visual Studies located in southern California.

ARTHI 500.title: Apprentice Teaching
ARTHI 500.prereq_description: Graduate standing; consent of instructor; department approval.
ARTHI 500.description: For teaching assistants, course includes directed readings, instruction in use of visual aids, pedagogical techniques, design of materials for discussion sections, and methodological analyses. Attendance at lectures in the course to which the T.A. is assigned is a requirement.

ARTHI 595.title: Group Studies
ARTHI 595.prereq_description: Graduate standing; consent of instructor; department approval.
ARTHI 595.comments: No unit credit allowed toward degree.

ARTHI 596.title: Independent Study
ARTHI 596.prereq_description: Graduate standing; consent of instructor; department approval.
ARTHI 596.description: Individual tutorial. A written proposal must be approved by the department chair.

ARTHI 597.title: Reading for Examination
ARTHI 597.prereq_description: Graduate standing; consent of instructor; department approval.
ARTHI 597.description: Preparation for terminal M.A. or for Ph.D. Minor and Major exams.

ARTHI 598.title: Master's Thesis Preparation
ARTHI 598.prereq_description: Graduate standing; consent of instructor; department approval.
ARTHI 598.comments: No credit allowed toward degree. For Plan 1 student only.

ARTHI 599.title: Ph.D. Dissertation Preparation
ARTHI 599.prereq_description: Graduate standing; consent of instructor; department approval.
